Even harder now with HMO and PPO  telling patient what is covered under their insurance plan. This film provides an opportunity to empowerment-----ecouraging individuals to support each other and courageous fight for their own <loves ones> health.

Wow.....I love the Love Story......but I'm super frustrated by the storyline.....
I'll start from the end.... The doctor that misdiagnosed the wife is on the review panel to determine if she should remain on life support??? And another doctor who was worried about getting into the nurse's panties/scrubs? Really?
I can't understand the decision NOT to get 2nd opinions from a different hospital and different doctors.

I blame the husband 1000% for this. HE was supposed to be the advocate for his wife and child. And he failed them when it counted.

I blame the wife 35%.....we will change hairstylists if we get a bad cut once, but to stick with a doctor who ridicules your concerns? And disrespects you in front of your husband while chewing gum? I changed my ob when I was 3 months pregnant because I SENSED that the doctor was trying to "run" the show and wouldn't have taken my concerns seriously. I'm so glad I did...! It saved my life and health and that of my son.

Anyway, there are a LOT of messages in this movie.....
1. Be a team. 100% of the time. Not just when you aren't opposed.
2. Be your Loved one's advocate. Don't let the medical bureaucracy cost you your life, loved ones, relationships and health.
3. Follow your gut/instincts and don't back down. Men, trust a Woman's instinct. It is usually correct.
Love this movie

Very good psa movie but all those symptoms should have got a second opinion. I was yelling at the screen for the incompetence of the doctor and hint of malpractice.  First-time pregnancy i got every pregnancy book there was. Spoilers....
  glad everything worked out

I appreciate the intent of the creators of the film. A PSA about pregnancy complications is needed, and I think for the right target audience (those who do absolutely no research and trust their doctors blindly--I'm NOT that gal), this movie may work. But my main beef without giving the story away is how otherwise intelligent characters have a serious blind spot when it comes to trusting their doctors. Early in the story, I knew what was up, but yet the doctor in the movie (I'm not a doctor) didn't? Really? Okay. That rant is over. If you like R&B, you'll like the soundtrack. If you like a love story, and love the Lord, you might get through it okay if you're willing to suspend disbelief on the medical stuff--and give grace to the acting of some of the characters (and low budget). But it felt like a big cliche most of the time.
Other than the cussing, this is a good story based on the family's experience.  It was an eye-opener as the quality of care some women receive when pregnant.
This was an excellent! My wife and I really enjoyed it!

This really depicts the vulnerability of what women, especially black women go through enduring the medical profession.  Women, trust the signs of change in your body and what they are telling you which no doctor can.  In my family, the doctor tried to tell my mother and father they were crazy and at fault.  As a result, 3 siblings died before me until my dad changed doctors - hence I was born.  Therefore, we must be our own advocate and stand up to authority figures who try to diminish our importance and silence our voice.  This movie explores all of these raw sentiments and gave us a happy ending based on the real life survival story of Angel Burgin Logan being diagnosed with proclamsia throughout her pregnancy.  However, that is not the norm.
Beautiful! I was actually teary watching this movie :(
